div3.head: Killed in action.
div3.p:
--Capt. Ed. W. Branch, of the Richmond Grays, 12th Va. regiment, was killed on Friday last in a skirmish in Culpeper county, while his company was on picket duty.
Capt. B. was a brave soldier and excellent officer.

div3.head: Stealing Cattle.
div3.p:
--Sylvanus T. Brown, a Charles City free negro, was arraigned before the Recorder last Saturday to answer the charge of stealing two calves from Nathaniel Lawrence, on Wednesday night last.
At an early hour on Thursday morning Mr. Lawrence missed his veals, and taking the tracks of the cart in which they were hauled away, came on to Richmond.
By inquiry at the first market last Friday morning, he ascertained that his two calves had been sold to Mr. Wm. Braner, a butcher, for $180. Mr. B., finding that he had unintentionally purchased stolen stock of a free negro, gave them up, and started in pursuit of the thief.
After riding some eight or nine miles he came up with Brown, recovered all his money but three dollars, brought him back to the city, and delivered him to the police.
Brown proved by two other free negroes that he purchased the calves of another negro, while on the road to Richmond, at night, and gave $50 for each of them; but neither the witnesses nor the prisoner could tell who that negro was, nor whether slave or free.
The Recorder remanded him for felony, to be examined at the next term of the Hustings Court, and committed him to jail for safe keeping.
[Brown had a certificate of good character from a Justice of his county, and has generally been regarded as an honest trader, or market man]

div3.head: Local defence.
div3.p:
--To-day is the time appointed for a meeting of that class of citizens of Henrico county not subject to conscription, but who are ready and willing to give some tangible assurance of their determination to protect their homes and firesides against the encroachments of the common enemy.
Once more the soil of Virginia is desecrated by the polluting steps of Yankee hirelings, seeking our general destruction.
To Gen. Lee belongs the duty of chastising and routing their main army; but to the people — the fathers and brothers of our gallant soldiery in the field — is entrusted the labor of caring for the raiders and strolling thieves and plunderers that will attempt to permeate every neighborhood, and if they fail to attempt to perform their part of the labor, they merit all the punishment that the foe can inflict.
Let the old men, and the exempts meet at the court-house and organize to day — let the boys under eighteen form companies and select prudent, skillful commanders — let all who can mount a horse or fire a shot-gun, or give a signal, prepare for action.--let every by-way, every bridge, every ditch, become a barrier to the foe, so that he may find no rest for his feet, save that rest which death awarded.
We have no time to lose now, men of Henrico.
If you are ready to become slaves to the Northern horde, stay at home; but if you desire liberty for yourself and your children, organize at once and be prepared to strike effectively for your altars and your homes.

Counterfeit Confederate Notes, lithographed in Yankee land, where wooden nutmegs and leather hams were manufactured and extensively sold a few years ago, were passed on many of our soldiers when in Pennsylvania as genuine, and are now being circulated by them in many parts of this Confederacy.
Some of these notes are so admirably executed that none but judges of money can detect them.
Several have been received by traders at the first market, who did not discover the character of the money till they offered it at bank.

div3.head: Good characters.
div3.p:
--But a few days since the City Council, in order to prevent communication between our lines and those of the Yankees, through free negro mediums, passed an ordinance authorizing the arrest of all persons of that character trading to Richmond from other counties, who did not have certificates of good character and loyalty from Justices of the Peace of their counties.
On Saturday last a Charles City free negro, with a certificate of character, and a regular trader, was before the Recorder, charged with having stolen two calves while on his way to market, which he sold in this city for $180. So much for the character of this race of beings, and for the policy of allowing them to trade here under any circumstances.

div3.head: Prison record.
div3.p:
--On Saturday afternoon about one hundred Yankee prisoners were booked at the Libby prison.
They were sent down from Gordonsville.
There were no arrivals yesterday.
In the morning 780 Yankees were sent off to take the flag-of truce boat at City Point.
At Castle Thunder there were some half dozen arrivals during the day yesterday, among them James Jones, a Yankee deserter.

div3.head: Pardoned.
div3.p: --Young Robinson, sent to the Penitentiary from the C. S. Court of this city, some few weeks since for forging pay rolls, was pardoned by President Davis on Saturday last.

div3.head: Stealing a watch.
div3.p: --John Bolton and James W. Perry, charged with stealing a gold watch and chain from George Sinton, were examined before the Recorder last Saturday, and after a hearing were remanded to the Hustings Court for a further hearing.

div3.head: Stealing shoes.
div3.p: --A free negro called Valvin Mann was punished by order of the Recorder for stealing a pair of shoes and other articles from a negro girl who was authorized to sell them.

Henrico County Court, through its members, have disbursed among the poor of the county about $14,000 in money, and yet have failed to satisfy the demands of public charity.
As this fund was designed to relieve the needy families of soldiers in the army it would have been far better to have purchased and distributed provisions.
The Court could certainly buy large quantities on better terms than families could small quantities, and then they would know who the real needy were, and what relief was given them.

The Depreciation of the Currency, caused principally by the demand of blockaders for gold, is oppressing the poor of all classes, but especially needle women, many of whom have large families to support, and find great difficulty in earning enough to buy a small amount of the commonest fare.
As gold becomes more scarce the depreciation will continue, until finally it will be rejected altogether.
If the Government would seize and confiscate all Yankee goods brought into the Confederacy, and would allow no cotton to go out, except on its own account, the present state of things would speedily improve, and the poor would be greatly relieved.
Whatever the cause, gold and silver will ever be the standard currency, and as long as the Government permits specie to be carried off and expended for Yankee trash our Treasury issues will be valuable only to the extent to which they will purchase gold.

Every Person charge with crime, be he white or black, has a right to hear the evidence against him, and to cross question the witness, either in person or through counsel.
Many of the new watch in testifying before the Mayor seem not to be aware of the fact, and instead of speaking out so they can be heard, lean up to the Mayor as if imparting a secret, and so mouth their words that no one can understand what they say. In re-arranging the police court room, it would be well to erect a witness stand, equidistant between the Mayor's seat and the bar, so that proof of all charges could be distinctly heard.

The Treasury Department, when the old Post Office rooms are put in order, will be complete and convenient, as the pay office is to be on the Main street floor, opposite the banks.
Secretary Memminger will now have immediately under his eyes the most important bureaus of his charge, and will be enabled to see that all branches are properly systematized and operated.
If the building were sufficiently large to accommodate all the bureaus the Confederacy would be vastly benefited.

A Superannuated Beggar, who gave his name as William McMillan, and who spends his charity receipts in bad whiskey, was committed to jail by the Recorder as a common nuisance, in default of bail for his good behavior.
Recorder Caskie, in the absence of the Mayor, held police court at the City Hall last Saturday, and promptly disposed of the business before him.
The County Court of Henrico will commence its August term to-day.

div4.head: Obituaries.
div4.p: Died at the residence of his parents, on Church Hill, Richmond, Va Robert Edwine Farnar son of Robert and Elizabeth Farrer at 2½ o'clock Sunday evening July 26th, 1863, aged 17 years 8 months and 26 days.

After an illness of eleven weeks, having passed through one of the most severe ordeals of pain and suffering ever allod to man, he gently sank to rest.
He was ided a great sufferer; rarely have human eyes rested upon a scene more deeply touching, more afflicting, more calculated to enlist the tenderest sympathies of the soul; vet he core his sufferings with great, fortitudes and patience The ensanguined plain of martial dd affords no more indubitable evidences of heroism than he manifested while under trial, for he was conscious of approaching danger; he knew that he would soon encounter the fiercest enemy known to man — Death, relentless Death But it was not left for him to die on the bloody field of war. He passed away in the bosom of home, in the midst of those who loved him. Could human skill or the appliances of love and affection have saved him he would not have gone.
But, Sonnie, dear Sonnie, could not stay with us. He was perfectly resigned to the will of his Heavenly Father.
Never did he murmur never did he say "it isn't right;" he said he wanted to go. During his inst moments, when the loved ones were we spring over him he said, "Don't do so, that isn't right; this is nothing.
I am going home; Heaven is my home; I shall soon be there where sickness and sorrow, pain and death, are felt and feared no more." One by one he told father, mother, brothers and sisters, good-bye and "Meet me there," were his parting words Sonic is sleeping beneath the ceder at the old homestead, where he told his Ma. he wished to be placed when he was gone.
B'Neath the shade of the old ceder and the locust by its side, he sleeps, and there ofttimes will the tear of remembrance beden his grave and the hand of loved ones plant sweet flowers of affection above him, which, blooming in freshness and beauty with the morning sun and then decaying in the eventide shall tell the sad story of his early death, and that upon all things earthly is written, in unmistakable characters — Passing away.

But the loved ones may not mourn as those who have no hope.
He left the most indubitable evidences behind him that he was going to another and a better land than this — that sun- bright clime above.
His last moments were very peaceful.
The gliding stream (than he was) runs not more placid

Among the many noble song of the South that have fallen in defence of her honor and rights there is none who deserted more praise than Sergeant John C. Wood who fell mortally wounded, nobly defending Port Hudson on the 27th of May, 1863, and expired on the 21st of May in the arms of one of his comrades.
He devoted brothers and sisters, who seemed to think nothing too good for their darling brother and he in return thought the game of them.
He left them all and sought the tented field, where he knew nothing awaited him but trials and hardships of a soldier's life, but nobly did he respond to his country's call, and bravely did he struggle for her independence, for he thought there was nothing five dying a patriot's death.
It was not in his own dear State that he was seen to fall but far off in Louisiana his blood was shed and his manly form left to dey; but now his grave is too far away to be watched by the tear of his relatives and friends; but yet he is fresh in their memory, and never to be forgotten by his loved ones at home.
Although he was relieved from his gun, he rushed madly out to do his duty, and received that fatal shot.
Fare well, dear brother.
